M: Well, Lisa, I need some money.

W: How much?

M: Hmm, I think $600 will be OK. I have some.

W: Oh, that’s a lot. What’s for?

M: ①Nightwish is having their live performance at the Capital Stadium this weekend. I certainly can’t miss it, you know.

W: Oh my! That’s not worth it. It doesn’t make too much difference to watch the recorded concert.

M: You simply can’t understand it. ②I’ve been looking forward to this moment for ages. It means so much to me. My heart will stop, I’m afraid.

W: I really couldn’t see why you guys get so mad about those stars.

M: Um … listening to her CDs always makes me relaxed. I’ll go no matter what. You’ll lend me the money, won’t you?

W: Alright, alright. I can’t destroy your dream.

M: Wow, millions of thanks.

[{"id":6266,"main_id":51468,"questions":1,"subject":"What is the man busy doing? ","answer":"A. Preparing a play.","answer_a":"A. Preparing a play.","answer_b":"B. Working on his paper.","answer_c":"C. Meeting with people from different groups.","answer_d":"","highlight":"","analysis":"

M: Hey Susie! How’ve you been?

W: Not so well …  I have to hand in a paper on Monday. That is killing me! I keep sitting down to work on it, but just end up with nothing. I paid attention in class, but I just don’t think I understand the task quite right.

M: Yeah, be patient. ①I’m preparing a play. My group have already met many times, but we aren’t quite ready yet.

W: Oh, I’m really looking forward to Spring Break.

M: Me, too. ②Will you come to Jason’s birthday party tonight?

W: Well, actually I made plans with my mum to take part in a 10-kilometer run to help the cancer research on Saturday morning.

M: But if you want to drop by earlier this evening, feel free.

W: Uh … ②Maybe I’ll see you tonight. Will you come to the race tomorrow?

M: Alright. ③I actually know a brave kid fighting cancer and I want to help people with cancer, so it’s a cause that really makes me make up my mind.

M: Hey Susie! How’ve you been?

W: Not so well …  I have to hand in a paper on Monday. That is killing me! I keep sitting down to work on it, but just end up with nothing. I paid attention in class, but I just don’t think I understand the task quite right.

M: Yeah, be patient. ①I’m preparing a play. My group have already met many times, but we aren’t quite ready yet.

W: Hi, I’m Sandra and I’m one of your activity leaders. I would like to welcome you all to Sun and Sea Summer Camp. I would just like to explain a little about the camp program.

The camp is built in a traditional village style. It has very large rooms with a fridge, TV, air-conditioning and all other useful equipment. It can comfortably hold 4 people.

The Sun and Sea Camp welcomes up to 20 children, aged 12-17. In the morning, there are 2 programs to choose from: the Adventure Camp and the English Language Camp. After the morning activities and lessons have finished it’s time for a healthy lunch. ①After lunch there is a rest time during the hottest hours of the day, which is from 1:30 p.m. to 3:30 p.m. Then the popular All-Camp meeting starts the afternoons where a series of exciting activities take place in age groups.

②Every evening there are special events planned. They are mainly cultural visits and some of these will certainly be among the most interesting parts of your 2-week experience.

That’s it for now. ③So, let me get you all to your rooms and on to lunch so we can all get to know each other.

W: Hey, Dave. I’m not surprised to run into you here. What are you up to?

M: Just looking for some new music.

W: This is the Country section, you know? What about this one, New Country by Benny?

M: I like Benny’s country music. But I’ve got that one already.

W: Alright. How about Krissy Holt?

M: Yeah, her folk music is great, but I need something more joyful.

W: Look, here’s Styx’s latest CD. In my opinion, Styx is the greatest hip hop band.

M: Yeah, they’re creative. I’ll get their CD.

W: OK. What else is in there? Don’t tell me you listen to boy bands.

M: No way, ①any musician is more talented than boy bands. They just sing on their looks …

W: Well, what about Fly’s rock music? He writes good music.

M: Great. I’ll get Fly’s latest CD. Well, I think that’s enough for now. ②Do you want to come over to my place and listen to your new CDs?

M: ②Why not?

M: We have the exciting news to give you today. Our yearly Young Person’s Short Story Competition is open now.

The competition is open to anyone aged between 13 and 18. Your story should be between 3,000 words and 10,000 words long. It must have a title.

This is the fourth year of the competition and this year there is an extra subject. The regular subjects of “comedy”, “mystery” are still choices but  this year we have added the theme of “world travel”.

This year’s judges are the successful writer of travel books, Bob Johnson, ① children’s author, Jenny Paige and short story writer, Alan Dobson.

There are some amazing prizes: first prize is £5,000; second prize is £2,000 and third prize is £1,000. ⑤The winning stories will be published in the major literature magazine, New Authors.

So get your thinking hats on. ③The deadline is Friday 25th September. And a week after that on 1st October we will read out the results. For more information, visit our website, www.youngwriters.competition.co.uk.

M: Senior high school is over, but you don’t seem happy.

W: ①Study or work, it’s hard to choose. I don’t even know what to study.

M: ②How about arts? You’re good at drawing.

W: ②That’s what my parents want me to do.

M: You should take their advice. They know what’s best for you.

W: But my friends will have jobs and lots of fun while I spend all my time doing reading and writing.

M: But if you go to university, you’ll still have time for fun.

W: Umm. What you say makes sense. But, you know, I still have to ask my parents for pocket money and I hate to do so at this age …

M: ③If you try to find a part-time job, you will have some money.

W: That’s a good idea! Thank you for the advice.

W: Guess who I saw in town this morning?

M: Who?

W: Philip. He has passed the test to be a doctor. ①He is working in a restaurant.

M: Funny job for a doctor.

W: ②He’s saving money. He told me that he was going to work abroad. He wants to help people. But he said that he’d be back next June. Then he’ll start working as a doctor.

M: Hmm.

W: He told me the flight was about $800. And then he said he was working seven days a week. Well, I don’t think he should have to work that hard, do you?

M: Yes … er … I mean no.

W: Good. I’m so glad you agree. Because I told him we’d pay for his ticket.

M: What?!

W: Yes, he was very happy. So I got the money out of the bank this afternoon and I gave it to him and told him that it was a present from both of us.

W: I had never really thought about modeling. I don’t even think I knew what it was or at least what it meant, you know … that it could actually be your job.

①I’d read a magazine article about MIKAs, my modeling agency, back in 2006. I thought it sounded interesting but I still had  two more years of high school. It was in the autumn of 2006 when my big chance came. My cousins had come to visit me and we were walking around central Stockholm where I live.

②A man walked up to me and I thought he was going to ask me directions somewhere, but instead he offered me a modeling job. He gave me the phone number of the agency and asked me to call them. My parents were a bit worried but we did call them.

③Mum went with me to the interview and MIKAs explained a lot about the business and answered Mum’s many questions.

They took a few simple photos and three days later they called me back for my first job, a photo shoot for a make-up company.

④I was so nervous that I thought MIKAs would ask me to leave, but it was fantastic and since that day I’ve had to work almost every week confidently.

W: Hello, everyone. I’d like to tell you why I set up the running club. When I injured my back several years ago, I had to take a break from running. I decided to introduce more women to the sport, ②to show them how much fun it can be and to give them the confidence to get out and run.

I decided to start a running club for women in my area. I put up advertisements and 40 women joined. ③All of them were attracted by the idea of losing weight but I don’t think they had really thought about running before. When or if they did, they had a picture of painful training. They didn’t think of chatting or smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river.

At first they ran for only a minute — now they can run for thirty minutes. ④I’ve had so much pleasure watching their progress— almost as much as they’ve had themselves.

W: Hello, everyone. I’d like to tell you why I set up the running club. When I injured my back several years ago, I had to take a break from running. I decided to introduce more women to the sport, ②to show them how much fun it can be and to give them the confidence to get out and run.

I decided to start a running club for women in my area. I put up advertisements and 40 women joined. ③All of them were attracted by the idea of losing weight but I don’t think they had really thought about running before. When or if they did, they had a picture of painful training. They didn’t think of chatting or smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river.

At first they ran for only a minute — now they can run for thirty minutes. ④I’ve had so much pleasure watching their progress— almost as much as they’ve had themselves.

W: Hello, everyone. I’d like to tell you why I set up the running club. When I injured my back several years ago, I had to take a break from running. I decided to introduce more women to the sport, ②to show them how much fun it can be and to give them the confidence to get out and run.

I decided to start a running club for women in my area. I put up advertisements and 40 women joined. ③All of them were attracted by the idea of losing weight but I don’t think they had really thought about running before. When or if they did, they had a picture of painful training. They didn’t think of chatting or smiling while running in beautiful places, like by a river.

At first they ran for only a minute — now they can run for thirty minutes. ④I’ve had so much pleasure watching their progress— almost as much as they’ve had themselves.
